landing.title: SpectrumSense
landing.subtitle: Discover Your Color Perception Boundaries
landing.description: Everyone perceives color boundaries differently. This test uses binary search to find exactly where you see Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, and Violet on the color spectrum.
landing.disclaimer: Works best on a calibrated display in a neutral lighting environment.
landing.how_step1: You see a color and choose which of two adjacent color names it's closer to
landing.how_step2: Your answers drive a binary search that narrows in on each of the 7 color boundaries
landing.how_step3: Your personal color map is compared against typical boundary values
landing.boundaries_desc: The standard boundaries are: Red→Orange at 18°, Orange→Yellow at 48°, Yellow→Green at 78°, Green→Blue at 163°, Blue→Violet at 258°, Violet→Pink at 300°, and Pink→Red at 345° on the HSL color wheel. These values come from the XKCD color survey (N=222,500), the Munsell color system, and CIE colorimetry research.
landing.reliability_desc: The test employs several psychometric techniques: practice trials before scoring begins, randomized boundary order to prevent priming, left-right counterbalancing to cancel position bias, a neutral gray interstitial between questions to reset color adaptation, and adaptive step expansion for oscillating responses.
test.env_brightness: Set your screen brightness to maximum
test.env_nightmode: Disable Night Shift / Blue Light Filter
test.env_lighting: Use neutral ambient lighting if possible
test.instruction: Which color is this closer to?
test.refine_prompt: Want more precision? Refine your boundaries.
test.real_test_message: The real test begins now. Your responses will be recorded.
test.how_note: Question count may increase slightly based on your response patterns.
results.title: Your Color Boundaries
results.subtitle: How your perception compares to typical boundaries
results.disclaimer: Note: HSL is not perceptually uniform. A 10° shift near yellow appears larger than near green. These boundaries reflect typical perception, not absolute standards.
